IRS990.ActivityOrMissionDesc: PROMOTING SCHOOL CHOICE IN ORDER TO IMPROVE, THROUGH COMPETITION, K-12 EDUCATION FOR ALL.
IRS990.MissionDesc: THE FOUNDATION WAS ESTABLISHED BY MILTON AND ROSE D. FRIEDMAN IN 1996 TO EDUCATE THE PUBLIC ON THE NEED FOR AND BENEFITS OF PARENTAL SCHOOL CHOICE. OUR EDUCATIONAL WORK INCLUDES RESEARCH, COMMUNICATIONS AND MARKETING, PUBLIC OUTREACH, AND GRANT-MAKING.
IRS990.Desc: GRANT MAKING: THE FOUNDATION AWARDED 79 GRANTS TO CHARITABLE ORGANIZATIONS FOR EDUCATIONAL PURPOSES.

ProgSrvcAccomActy2Grp.Desc: EDUCATION ACTIVITIES - THE FOUNDATION WORKED AROUND THE COUNTRY TO EDUCATE THE PUBLIC ON THE PRACTICE AND BENEFITS OF SCHOOL CHOICE, IN EACH INSTANCE PROVIDING EDUCATIONAL SERVICES TO STATE-BASED ORGANIZATIONS, INDIVIDUALS AND POLICY MAKERS. THESE SERVICES INCLUDE: SPONSORING FACT-FINDING TRIPS TO CITIES/STATES WITH SCHOOL CHOICE PROGRAMS; HOSTING INFORMATIONAL SYMPOSIUMS; SPONSORING VISITS BY EXPERT SPEAKERS; TESTIFYING IN FRONT OF VARIOUS LEGISLATIVE BODIES AT THEIR REQUEST; PARENT EDUCATION EFFORTS AND TRAINING; MEDIA SUPPORT AND MEDIA TRAINING; PROVIDING TECHNICAL ADVICE ON THE DRAFTING OF LEGISLATION; AND SPONSORING MEETINGS WITH FOUNDATION STAFF AND VARIOUS SCHOOL CHOICE EXPERTS.

ProgSrvcAccomActy3Grp.Desc: RESEARCH AND COMMUNICATION - THE FOUNDATION PRODUCED PUBLICATIONS AND RESEARCH REPORTS INCLUDING, BUT NOT LIMITED TO, ITS QUARTERLY NEWSLETTER (THE SCHOOL CHOICE ADVOCATE); STATE AND NATIONAL RESEARCH REPORTS; PUBLIC POLICY SURVEYS; AND OUR ANNUAL BROCHURE ENTITLED THE ABC'S OF SCHOOL CHOICE. THE FOUNDATION PRODUCED EDUCATIONAL MARKETING FLIERS AND PROMOTIONAL BROCHURES FOR STATE SCHOOL CHOICE PARTNERS. THE FOUNDATION UNDERTOOK POLLS IN EFFORTS TO GAUGE PUBLIC OPINION.

SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: CORRECTION MADE: The Foundation reimburses expenses individuals incur to attend the Foundations educational legislative summits. Instead of reimbursing two individuals for the expenses they incurred in attending a legislative summit, the reimbursements were inadvertently issued to the individuals political campaigns. When the Foundation discovered the reimbursements were issued to political campaigns rather than the state legislators in their individual capacity, the Foundation promptly requested that the funds be returned and issued replacement checks to the individual legislators once all the funds had been recovered by the Foundation. The Foundation has filed Form 4720 and has requested full abatement of all taxes, penalties and interest under Section 4962 of the Internal Revenue Code. Accordingly, the Foundation has reported no taxes incurred on Schedule C, Part I-B, Line 1.

LOBBYING EXPENDITURES TO INFLUENCE PUBLIC OPINION: THE FRIEDMAN FOUNDATION FOR EDUCATIONAL CHOICE IS NEVER INVOLVED IN POLITICAL CAMPAIGNS. THE SUBSTANTIAL ACTIVITY UNDERTAKEN BY THE FRIEDMAN FOUNDATION FOR EDUCATIONAL CHOICE IS EDUCATIONAL IN NATURE. THE FOUNDATION HAS MADE AN ELECTION UNDER SECTION 501(H) OF THE INTERNAL REVENUE CODE. CONSISTENT WITH AN ORGANIZATION EXEMPT UNDER CODE SECTION 501(C)(3) WITH "H ELECTION," THE FOUNDATION ALSO UNDERTAKES LIMITED LOBBYING ACTIVITIES IN CERTAIN STATES TO AID IN THE PASSAGE OF LEGISLATION THAT ENABLES PARENTS TO RECEIVE A PUBLICLY FUNDED VOUCHER OR A TAX CREDIT FUNDED SCHOLARSHIP TO SEND THEIR CHILDREN TO APPROVED PRIVATE SCHOOLS. IN 2015, THESE ACTIVITIES INCLUDED ALLOCATING STAFF TIME FOR DIRECT LOBBYING TO STATE LEGISLATORS AND ENCOURAGING THE GENERAL PUBLIC TO SUPPORT SPECIFIC LEGISLATION.

FIN 48 DISCLOSURE: MANAGEMENT HAS EVALUATED THEIR INCOME TAX POSITIONS UNDER THE GUIDANCE INCLUDED IN ASC 740. BASED ON ITS REVIEW, MANAGEMENT HAS NOT IDENTIFIED ANY MATERIAL UNCERTAIN TAX POSITIONS TO BE RECORDED OR DISCLOSED IN THE FINANCIAL STATEMENTS.

SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: HIGHEST PAID FUNDRAISER: THE FOUNDATION ENGAGED FUENTES STRATEGIC CONSULTING, INC., FOR THE FIRST TIME IN 2014. THIS ORGANIZATION IS WORKING ON DEVELOPING SIGNIFICANT NEW DONORS FOR THE FOUNDATION. THE FOUNDATION ANTICIPATES FUENTES GENERATING NEW DONORS FOR THE FOUNDATION IN 2016.

SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: MONITORING THE USE OF GRANT FUNDS: THE FOUNDATION ACCEPTS APPLICATIONS FOR GRANTS THAT CONFORM TO THE FOUNDATION'S TAX-EXEMPT PURPOSE AND EDUCATIONAL MISSION. APPLICATIONS MUST INCLUDE A DESCRIPTION OF THE PROJECT, AMOUNT REQUESTED, PROJECT BUDGET, METHOD TO EVALUATE SUCCESS, BOARD OF DIRECTORS LIST, AND FINANCIAL STATEMENTS. THE FOUNDATIONS PROGRAM STAFF REVIEWS THE REQUEST AND SUBMITS SUGGESTED GRANTS TO THE EXECUTIVE MANAGEMENT. AFTER APPROVAL, THE VICE PRESIDENT OF OPERATIONS REVIEWS THE REQUEST FOR PROPER DOCUMENTATION AND DRAFTS A GRANT AGREEMENT THAT REQUIRES ALL FUNDS BE USED IN FURTHERANCE OF A PERMISSABLE ACTIVITY UNDER CODE SECTION 501(C)(3), WHICH IS THEN SIGNED BY THE GRANTEE, AND THE PAYMENT IS MADE. PROGRAM STAFF WORKS CLOSELY WITH THE GRANTEE TO ENSURE COMPLIANCE WITH THE GRANT AGREEMENT AND ENSURE PROPER USE OF GRANT FUNDS. GRANTEES ARE REQUIRED TO SUBMIT A FINAL REPORT ON THE PROJECT, INCLUDING HOW FUNDS WERE USED, IN A TIMELY MANNER AS NOTED IN THE GRANT AGREEMENT.

PURPOSE OF GRANT OR ASSISTANCE: *100 BLACK MEN OF AMERICA INC. - Support to educate, stimulate interest, and support members, parents and other community members regarding the need for high-quality education and education reform. *ADVANCE AMERICA INC. - Support for community outreach and education for school choice in Indiana, including mailing, meetings and six educational emails on school choice. *Alabama Policy Institute Inc. - Support for educational marketing and outreach to defend and promote the Alabama Accountability Act and to inform parents about educational funding opportunities available to them for their children's education. *Americans for Prosperity Foundation - Support to help build a coalition of support for school choice in West Virginia through educational outreach, events, and marketing activities. *Beacon Center of Tennessee - Support to update "Following the Money: A Tennessee Education Spending Primer,to produce marketing materials, web info-graphics and other promotional materials to educate taxpayers and parents about education spending. Also, Support to highlight spending by local school districts and promote MySchoolSpending.com through paid advertising and media. *Black Alliance for Educational Options - Support for the 2015 Symposium in honor of Dr. Howard Fuller. *Caesar Rodney Institute - Support for educating the Delaware public, supporters and policymakers on Education Savings Accounts. *Chalkbeat, Inc. - Support for reporting on education reform issues in Indiana, including school choice and charter schools. *Education Action Group Foundation - Support for in-depth investigative reporting on key education reform issues in Indiana and Nevada. *Educational Choice Illinois - General operating support for bipartisan partnership-building for school choice in Illinois, particularly for communications. *Empower Mississippi & Empower Mississippi Foundation - Support for statewide educational campaign about educational choice, including 3-4 events per week, radio ads, social media, postcards and educational materials. *GreatSchools - Support for the Indianapolis GreatSchools website including hosting and maintenance. *Hispanic Council for Reform and Educational Options (HCREO) - General operating funding for Latin-focused education and coalition building in Illinois. *Illinois Policy Institute - Support for parent outreach and education efforts on school choice options in Waukegan, Illinois. *Institute for Quality Education - General operating support for educational activities to promote school choice in Indiana. *Intellectual Takeout - Support for educational marketing on the need for and benefits of school choice to increase public awareness and support across Minnesota. *Iowa Advocates for Choice in Education - Support to hire a local lobbyist to assist with ESA efforts. *Kansas Policy Institute - General operating support for educational activities to promote school choice in Kansas. *Network for Educational Opportunity - Support for marketing and outreach to students and donors for New Hampshire's Education Tax Credit program. *Nevada Policy Research Institute - Support to conduct school choice research in Nevada, outreach to school choice constituencies, and to create a marketing campaign to inform the public on the need for school choice. *New Hampshire Center for Economic Policy - Support to educate school districts, parents, community leaders, and policymakers about the importance of New Hamphsire's town tuitioning system, and the current threat to this system. Grantee will produce studies, op-eds and online ads, host informational meetings, build support in the community, and support the legal effort to save town tuitioning. *Oklahoma Council of Public Affairs Inc - General operating support, including support for the Milton Friedman Distinguished Fellow. Also, General operating support for educational activities, including support for outreach to minority and rural communities. *Palmetto Promise Institute - Support to educate the public and school choice supporters on the Exceptional Needs Tax Credit Scholarship program. *Parents for Educational Freedom in North Carolina Inc. - General operating support for outreach to private schools and to educate families on accessing North Carolina's school choice programs. *Platte Institute for Economic Research - Support for outreach regarding Nebraska's education climate as well as hosting educational information sessions around the state. *Rhode Island Center for Freedom and Prosperity - Support for outreach to increase support for school choice, especially for hard-to-reach communities. *Thomas Jefferson Institute for Public Policy - Support to fund research evaluating the fiscal impact and savings of Virginia's tax credit scholarship program, to produce a study highlighting statewide achievement scores disaggregated by student demographics, and to support public outreach and education on the research findings. *THE FOLLOWING ORGANIZATIONS RECEIVED ADDITIONAL SUPPORT, WHICH IS INCLUDED IN THE AMOUNTS REPORTED ON PART II, TO HOST OR COORDINATE AN EVENT ON JULY 31, 2015, TO HONOR THE LEGACY OF MILTON FRIEDMAN AND HIS IDEAS: *Americans For Prosperity Foundation *Bluegrass Institute for Public Policy Solutions Inc *Caesar Rodney Institute *Hispanic American Center for Economic Research *Kansas Policy Institute *Nevada Policy Research Institute *Oklahoma Council of Public Affairs, Inc. *Rhode Island Center for Freedom and Prosperity *Thomas Jefferson Institute for Public Policy

COMPLIANCE WITH BACKUP WITHHOLDING RULES: THE FOUNDATION WAS NOT REQUIRED TO COMPLY WITH THE BACKUP WITHHOLDING RULES BECAUSE IT DID NOT MAKE REPORTABLE PAYMENTS TO VENDORS OR PAY REPORTABLE GAMING (GAMBLING) WINNINGS TO PRIZE WINNERS.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: FORM 990, PART VI, SECTION A, LINE 2
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: KEY OFFICER OR EMPLOYEE WITH FAMILY RELATIONSHIP WITH ANY OTHER OFFICER: JANET FRIEDMAN MARTEL AND DAVID D. FRIEDMAN ARE SIBLINGS.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: FORM 990, PART VI, SECTION B, LINE 11B
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: PROCESS TO REVIEW THE FORM 990: THE FORM 990 IS COMPLETED BY AN OUTSIDE ACCOUNTING FIRM, IN CONJUNCTION WITH THE FOUNDATION'S VICE PRESIDENT OF OPERATIONS AND CONTROLLER. THE FORM 990 IS REVIEWED BY THE FOUNDATION'S PRESIDENT & CEO, VICE PRESIDENT OF OPERATIONS, CONTROLLER, SECRETARY, AN INDEPENDENT ACCOUNTING FIRM AND AN OUTSIDE ATTORNEY. UPON COMPLETION, THE FINAL FORM 990 IS SENT TO THE FULL BOARD OF DIRECTORS FOR REVIEW BEFORE FILING.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: FORM 990, PART VI, SECTION B, LINE 12C
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: PROCESS FOR MONITORING COMPLIANCE WITH CONFLICT OF INTEREST POLICY: THE FOUNDATION'S BOARD OF DIRECTORS HAS ADOPTED A CONFLICT OF INTEREST POLICY THAT REQUIRES DIRECTORS, OFFICERS AND KEY EMPLOYEES TO SUBMIT AN ANNUAL CONFLICT OF INTEREST DISCLOSURE. THE ANNUAL DISCLOSURE REQUIRES DIRECTORS, OFFICERS AND KEY EMPLOYEES TO DISCLOSE, IN WRITING, ANY KNOWN FINANCIAL INTEREST THAT THE INDIVIDUAL (TOGETHER WITH FAMILY MEMBERS) HAS IN ANY BUSINESS ENTITY THAT TRANSACTS BUSINESS WITH THE FOUNDATION. IN ADDITION, DIRECTORS, OFFICERS AND KEY EMPLOYEES ARE REQUIRED TO IMMEDIATELY DISCLOSE ANY POSSIBLE CONFLICT OF INTEREST THAT ARISES MID-YEAR IN RELATION TO A PROPOSED TRANSACTION. THE CONFLICT OF INTEREST POLICY REQUIRES THAT ANY INDIVIDUAL WITH A CONFLICT BE RECUSED FROM THE DECISION-MAKING PROCESS, THAT INDEPENDENT DIRECTORS DETERMINE WHETHER THE PROPOSED TRANSACTION IS IN THE BEST INTERESTS OF THE FOUNDATION, AND THE TRANSACTION MUST BE APPROVED BY A VOTE OF THE INDEPENDENT DIRECTORS WITHOUT THE PARTICIPATION OF ANY INTERESTED INDIVIDUAL. THE ANNUAL CONFLICT DISCLOSURE STATEMENTS ARE SUBMITTED TO, AND REVIEWED BY, THE FOUNDATION'S VICE PRESIDENT OF OPERATIONS. IN ADDITION, THE EXECUTIVE STAFF OF THE FOUNDATION ARE RESPONSIBLE FOR MONITORING ANY POSSIBLE CONFLICT TRANSACTIONS THAT ARISE AND MANAGING THEM TO ENSURE THAT ALL TRANSACTIONS REPRESENT ARMS' LENGTH, FAIR MARKET VALUE TERMS FOR THE BENEFIT OF THE FOUNDATION.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: FORM 990, PART VI, SECTION B, LINE 15A
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: REVIEW OF CEO OR TOP MANAGEMENT OFFICIAL COMPENSATION: THE FOUNDATION'S BOARD OF DIRECTORS HAS ADOPTED AN EXECUTIVE COMPENSATION AND INTERMEDIATE SANCTIONS POLICY. THE PURPOSE OF THE POLICY IS TO ENSURE THAT THE FOUNDATION'S COMPENSATION ARRANGEMENTS WITH RELATED PARTIES ARE EVALUATED AND ENTERED AT ARMS' LENGTH AND THAT ANY COMPENSATION THAT IS PAID TO A RELATED PARTY IS REASONABLE AND REFLECTS FAIR MARKET VALUE. THE POLICY ENCOURAGES THE APPLICATION OF THE REBUTTABLE PRESUMPTION STANDARD OF CODE SECTION 4958 AND THE RELATED TREASURY REGULATIONS BY (A) EXCLUDING ANY INTERESTED PARTY FROM THE DECISION-MAKING PROCESS; (B) REQUIRING DISINTERESTED BOARD MEMBERS TO OBTAIN AND RELY UPON COMPARABILITY DATA WHEN SETTING THE PROPOSED COMPENSATION TERMS; (C) REQUIRING APPROVAL OF THE TRANSACTION IN ADVANCE BY DISINTERESTED DIRECTORS; AND (D) REQUIRING CONTEMPORANEOUS DOCUMENTATION (I.E., MINUTES) REFLECTING THE DECISION AND THE PROCESS BY WHICH IT WAS MADE. ON DECEMBER 14, 2015, INDEPENDENT MEMBERS OF THE BOARD OF DIRECTORS, MEETING AS A SEPARATE COMMITTEE EVALUATED THE COMPENSATION OF THE PRESIDENT/CEO, EVALUATED COMPARABILITY DATA, AND USED SUCH DATA TO SET HIS COMPENSATION FOR 2016.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: FORM 990, PART VI, SECTION C, LINE 19
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: GOVERNING DOCUMENTS AVAILABLE TO THE PUBLIC: THE ORGANIZATION MAKES ITS GOVERNING DOCUMENTS, CONFLICT OF INTEREST POLICY, AND FINANCIAL STATEMENTS AVAILABLE TO THE PUBLIC UPON REQUEST.

PAYMENTS FOR TRAVEL FOR PUBLIC OFFICIALS: PAYMENTS ARE FOR TRAVEL EXPENSES INCURRED DURING FACT-FINDING EDUCATIONAL TRIPS AND EDUCATIONAL SEMINARS HOSTED BY THE FOUNDATION. EXPENSES COVERED INCLUDED TRANSPORTATION, HOTEL AND MEALS.
